title: Is YouTube going to replace Televisions? - Quora

response.answer_text: No more than any of the other internet-based video delivery services, although they’re trying to be a major player on their user-uploaded cat video base. The word “television” has become something of a humpty-dumpty term, meaning whatever the user wants it to mean. If you want to restrict it to broadcast channels arriving via antenna or cable, you’re welcome to, but if you’re one of those who says “I don’t watch (ew, ick) television, I watch Netflix, Hulu, YouTube, whatever” you need to come to terms with the fact that the technical platform that delivers Friends and South Park to your eyeballs is pretty much irrelevant to whether you “watch television” or not. “Television” is much more meaningful when it’s defined as “a service that delivers commercial video content to viewers” - and doesn’t get into a pointless VHS/Beta level of argument. And no, having no commercials doesn’t make the content non-commercial. On the other hand, the best definition I’ve been able to formulate is this: “Television is an audiovisual marketing medium that shows less‐overtly-promotional content part of the time..” Which again has nothing much to do with whether it’s big-four broadcast material or torrent flow on a hacked iPad, “ad free” or shows discrete commercials, or any other outdated notions of what constitutes “television.”

YouTube was an early example of a platform whereby people could access videos online. The quality is variable and there are constant issues with copyright. So, although it’s a good place to look for old music videos and excerpts from longer movies or TV shows, it’s much less reliable as a replacement for television. That said, other viewing platforms like Netflix are certainly changing viewing patterns drastically. Over time we are indeed less likely to rely on scheduled programming to watch entertainment and educational television. The old-fashioned channels may have an edge in terms of being the first to show dramas that they themselves commission (like “The Bodyguard”) but that’s about it. Still, it’s likely that TV will evolve, just as radio has. It’s still the best medium for visual news. And we must also remember that people in many parts of the world have neither the equipment nor the bandwith nor the money to watch anything other than free to air channels.
